questions.question: A 38-year-old patient with hypopigmented nodular lesions with anethesia over arm with ulnar nerve involvement underwent a biopsy and intradermal antigen test. Based on the image, which statement regarding the condition is most accurate?

options.A: Tuberculoid leprosy with a positive antigen test
options.B: Lepromatous leprosy with a positive antigen test
options.C: Erythema nodosum leprosum with a negative antigen test
options.D: Lepromatous leprosy with a negative antigen test

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Lepromatous leprosy with a negative antigen test Explanation: The clinical presentation of this 38-year-old patient includes: Multiple hypopigmented nodular skin lesions Loss of sensation (anaesthesia) Involvement of peripheral nerves (ulnar nerve) Biopsy and intradermal antigen test (likely the Lepromin test) These features are most consistent with lepromatous leprosy , a multibacillary form of Hansen’s disease. Feature Description Skin lesions Numerous, symmetric, poorly defined, nodular or macular Sensory loss Late, diffuse Nerve involvement Multiple nerves, symmetrically Immune response Weak or absent cell-mediated immunity (CMI) Lepromin (Mitsuda) test Negative (due to poor CMI) Bacillary load High Histopathology Numerous acid-fast bacilli, foamy macrophages Tuberculoid leprosy with a positive antigen test (Option A): Tuberculoid form presents with few well-demarcated lesions , strong CMI, positive Lepromin test — not nodular lesions or widespread nerve involvement. questions.question: What is the preferred treatment for a pregnant woman who is 12 weeks pregnant and undergoing multidrug therapy for leprosy but is now experiencing type 2 lepra reaction?

options.A: Stop MDT and start oral steroids
options.C: Thalidomide Continue MDT and add oral steroids
options.D: Continue MDT and add oral steroids

questions.explanation: nodosum leprosum, ENL) is an immune complex-mediated reaction seen in multibacillary leprosy. Pregnancy does not alter the management of leprosy itself, and stopping multidrug therapy (MDT) is not recommended. The preferred treatment for type 2 reactions includes oral corticosteroids , which are safe in pregnancy. Thalidomide is strictly contraindicated due to teratogenicity. Leprosy and Its Management in Pregnancy Aspect Details Cause of Leprosy Mycobacterium leprae Types of Reactions Type 1 (Reversal), Type 2 (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum) Type 2 Lepra Reaction Immune complex-mediated (Type III hypersensitivity) Common Symptoms Painful nodules, fever, malaise, neuritis Management of Type 2 Reaction Corticosteroids (safe in pregnancy) Role of MDT in Pregnancy Must be continued to prevent relapse Drugs to Avoid Thalidomide (teratogenic) Management of Type 2 Lepra Reaction in Pregnancy Aspect Details Continue MDT Essential to prevent disease relapse Preferred drug Oral steroids (prednisolone) Avoid in pregnancy Thalidomide (teratogenic, causes phocomelia) Supportive therapy Analgesics, wound care if ulcerated lesions present Alternative options Clofazimine has mild immunomodulatory effects Stop MDT and start oral steroids (Option A) is incorrect because stopping MDT can lead to disease relapse and worsening nerve damage . MDT must be continued while managing the reaction with steroids. Antibiotics (Option B) is incorrect because type 2 lepra reaction is an inflammatory immune response , not an infectious complication. Antibiotics have no role in managing ENL itself. Thalidomide (Option C) is incorrect because thalidomide is highly teratogenic (causing phocomelia and limb defects) and is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy. Although thalidomide is an effective treatment for ENL, it should never be used in pregnant women. Reference: Rook’s textbook of dermatology 9th edition page no.- 28.15 to 28.16 Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 211, 212

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient presents to the clinic with hypopigmented patches on the skin. On examination, there are a few well-demarcated, slightly raised lesions with a loss of sensation. Skin smears reveal no acid-fast bacilli. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: suggest leprosy rather than other dermatological conditions. Well-demarcated, slightly raised lesions are characteristic of paucibacillary leprosy , which presents with five or fewer skin lesions with nerve involvement. Skin smears revealing no acid-fast bacilli indicate a low bacterial load , confirming paucibacillary leprosy rather than multibacillary leprosy . Leprosy: Leprosy (Hansen’s disease) is a chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae , primarily affecting the skin, peripheral nerves, and mucosa of the upper respiratory tract . It presents in a spectrum based on bacterial load and immune response. Classification of Leprosy (Ridley-Jopling & WHO Classification) Type Immune Response Skin Lesions Nerve Involvement AFB Smear WHO Classification Tuberculoid (TT) Strong (Th1) Few, well-defined, anesthetic Single nerve thickening Negative Paucibacillary (PB) Borderline Tuberculoid (BT) Moderate Multiple, asymmetric, anesthetic Multiple nerves affected Variable Paucibacillary (PB) Borderline Borderline (BB) Unstable Numerous, irregular plaques Moderate nerve involvement Positive Multibacillary (MB) Borderline Lepromatous (BL) Weak (Th2) Diffuse, infiltrative lesions Severe nerve damage Strongly Positive Multibacillary (MB) Lepromatous (LL) Absent Diffuse, nodular, leonine facies Symmetric nerve thickening Strongly Positive Multibacillary (MB) Clinical Features of Leprosy System Involved Clinical Features Skin Hypopigmented or erythematous macules, plaques, nodules, loss of sweating (anhidrosis) Nerves Thickened peripheral nerves, sensory loss (glove and stocking pattern) Eyes Lagophthalmos, keratitis, blindness Musculoskeletal Claw hand, foot drop, joint deformities Systemic Testicular atrophy, gynecomastia (LL type) Diagnosis of Leprosy Diagnostic Method Findings Clinical Diagnosis Hypopigmented/anesthetic skin lesions, nerve thickening Skin Smear (Ziehl-Neelsen Stain) AFB seen in multibacillary leprosy but not in paucibacillary leprosy Lepromin Test Positive in tuberculoid leprosy , negative in lepromatous leprosy Skin Biopsy Granulomas in tuberculoid leprosy, foam cells in lepromatous leprosy Nerve Biopsy Shows caseation necrosis in tuberculoid type Treatment of Leprosy (WHO Multidrug Therapy – MDT) Type First-Line Treatment (Duration) Paucibacillary (PB) Rifampicin + Dapsone (6 months) Multibacillary (MB) Rifampicin + Dapsone + Clofazimine (12 months) Pregnancy & lactation : MDT is safe. Children : Treated with adjusted doses based on weight. Leprosy Reactions & Management Reaction Type Features Treatment Type 1 (Reversal) Inflammatory response in existing lesions, nerve damage Steroids (Prednisolone) Type 2 (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum - ENL) Painful nodules, fever, neuritis, systemic involvement Steroids, Clofazimine , avoid Thalidomide in pregnancy Lucio Phenomenon Ulcerative necrotizing lesions Rifampicin, Clofazimine Prevention & Public Health Measures BCG vaccine offers partial protection. Early diagnosis & MDT prevents transmission. Household contacts should be screened regularly. Reconstructive surgery for deformities in chronic cases.

questions.question: The image given below is characteristically seen in which of the following types of leprosy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Borderline leprosy Explanation: Borderline leprosy is part of the spectrum of Hansen’s disease (leprosy) and is characterised by: Variable number of hypopigmented or hyperpigmented lesions that are asymmetrically distributed. Patchy partial loss of sensation within the lesions, a key diagnostic clue. Borderline forms are unstable , and patients may shift toward either the lepromatous or tuberculoid pole. Scalp involvement is uncommon in most forms of leprosy but can be seen in borderline cases. Ridley-Jopling Classification of Leprosy: Tuberculoid leprosy (TT) – Few well-demarcated hypopigmented patches with complete loss of sensation . Strong cell-mediated immunity (CMI) . Borderline tuberculoid (BT) – Multiple asymmetrical lesions, less well-defined than TT, with some sensory loss. Borderline leprosy (BB) – Intermediate form, variable lesions with partial sensory loss , and patchy nerve involvement . questions.question: Which of the following will be the outcome of Leprosy , if left untreated.

options.B: Half of the cases resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure
options.C: Spontaneous remission is more common in children than in adults
options.D: Indeterminate leprosy have more remission than tuberculoid

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Indeterminate leprosy have more remission than tuberculoid Explanation: Indeterminate leprosy is the earliest form of leprosy, presenting with a single or few ill-defined hypopigmented macules and minimal sensory loss. In many cases, spontaneous remission occurs , particularly in individuals with a strong cell-mediated immune (CMI) response . Tuberculoid leprosy , while having a strong immune response, tends to be chronic and persistent , with less likelihood of spontaneous remission. Indeterminate Leprosy: Early, undifferentiated form of leprosy . Few hypopigmented macules with slight sensory impairment. Histopathology : Mild inflammation, sparse acid-fast bacilli (AFB) . Fate : Can resolve spontaneously (~25–75% of cases) . May progress to tuberculoid or lepromatous forms, depending on immune response. Tuberculoid Leprosy: Well-demarcated plaques with sensory loss , few lesions. Strong CMI response , granuloma formation. Less likely to remit spontaneously , tends to persist unless treated. Outcomes if Untreated: Indeterminate leprosy has a higher chance of spontaneous remission compared to tuberculoid leprosy. If it does not resolve, it may progress toward the tuberculoid or lepromatous spectrum based on immune status. No spontaneous remission is seen (Option A) is incorrect because spontaneous remission does occur , particularly in indeterminate and early tuberculoid leprosy , especially in individuals with good immunity. Half of the cases resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure (Option B) is incorrect because while some individuals clear the infection, the proportion is variable and not as high as 50% in all populations . Spontaneous remission is more common in children than in adults (Option C) is incorrect because although children may have a higher rate of spontaneous resolution , the likelihood of remission is more dependent on the type of leprosy (indeterminate vs tuberculoid) rather than age alone . Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology 9th edition page no.- 28.5, 28.6

questions.question: What would be your next best course of action when a patient undergoing multi-drug therapy (MDT) exhibits deterioration of preexisting lesions and nerve involvement?

options.C: Stop MDT thalidomide Continue MDT, start thalidomide

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Continue MDT, start systemic steroids Explanation: Deterioration of preexisting lesions + nerve involvement in a patient on MDT suggests Type 1 Lepra Reaction (Reversal Reaction) . Type 1 Reaction is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction in borderline leprosy due to increased cell-mediated immunity . Management: Continue MDT : The reaction is due to immune response, not drug failure. Start systemic corticosteroids (prednisolone) to reduce inflammation and prevent permanent nerve damage. Lepra Reactions Type Mechanism Clinical Features Management Type 1 (Reversal Reaction) Increased cell-mediated immunity (CMI) Worsening of existing lesions , erythema, edema, nerve pain Continue MDT , start systemic steroids (prednisolone) Type 2 (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum - ENL) Immune complex deposition (TNF- α mediated) Painful nodules , fever, neuritis, systemic symptoms Continue MDT , start thalidomide or steroids Stop MDT, start systemic corticosteroids (Option A): Incorrect because MDT should not be stopped ; the reaction is due to immune response, not drug toxicity. Stop MDT, start thalidomide (Option C): Incorrect because thalidomide is used for Type 2 reaction (ENL), not Type 1 reaction . Continue MDT, start thalidomide (Option D): Incorrect because thalidomide is ineffective for Type 1 reactions; steroids are preferred .

questions.question: For the diagnosis of neuritic leprosy, which nerve is typically subjected to a biopsy?
questions.explanation: primarily affects the peripheral nerves without significant skin involvement. It is characterized by nerve damage and inflammation, leading to sensory and motor impairments. To diagnose neuritic leprosy, a nerve biopsy is often performed to examine the affected nerve tissue for the presence of Mycobacterium leprae, the bacteria that causes leprosy. The superficial branch of the radial nerve is commonly chosen for the biopsy due to its accessibility and involvement in the affected nerve region. Incorrect options: Option A . Median nerve: The median nerve is not typically biopsied for the diagnosis of neuritic leprosy. While it can be affected in leprosy, it is not the primary nerve chosen for biopsy in cases of neuritic leprosy. Option C. Ulnar nerve: Similar to the median nerve, the ulnar nerve can be affected in leprosy, but it is not the nerve of choice for biopsy in cases of neuritic leprosy. Option D . Lateral popliteal nerve: The lateral popliteal nerve, also known as the common peroneal nerve, is not specifically associated with neuritic leprosy. While leprosy can affect peripheral nerves throughout the body, the superficial branch of the radial nerve is the nerve commonly biopsied for the diagnosis of neuritic leprosy, not the lateral popliteal nerve.
